awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Benchtop Analytical Scanning Electron Microscope
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation award supports the Fashion Institute of Technology [FIT] with the purchase of a tabletop analytical Scanning Electron Microscope [SEM] to foster on-campus research and improve undergraduate STEAM [Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, Mathematics] education. The use of SEM helps scientists overcome inherent limitation of optical microscopy. The electron beam in a SEM interacts with the sample and generates signals that are used to produce images and provide chemical identifications. This instrument supports in-house qualitative and quantitative characterization of various materials and enhances greatly the research and curatorial facility at FIT. This instrument also fosters internal collaborations, spanning from biomaterials and textile engineering to artistic endeavors. Design and production methods are becoming more technologically sophisticated. Creative industries therefore demand that design professionals possess the scientific literacy and interdisciplinary aptitude necessary to understand new materials and the underlying science, such as polymers, biomaterials and nanomaterials. Integrating sustainability into product design, development and manufacturing are other challenges for which FIT trains students. As a community college specializing in art and design, FIT is reaching across disciplines to better prepare students mostly women for the science aspects of their careers. Integrating the instrument in courses will impact many of the projects that FIT students undertake to fulfill their hands-on curricula. 

The acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope, SEM, at the Fashion Institute of Technology (FIT) enables interactive, cross-disciplinary research, and curatorial and industrial collaborations that focus on materials characterization.  The SEM will also enable the study of electron-beam interactions, to explore nanocoatings on items. In addition to promoting faculty research, the SEM will enhance the learning experience of FIT students related to the development and use of materials, and support and expand interdisciplinary/problem-based STEAM curricula and programs within the Science and Math department. The SEM will be integrated into current courses and used to develop new curricula. Students and faculty will have opportunities to work in well-equipped science laboratories that support materials research and development with advanced materials characterization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

Major Research Instrumentation

Title: Acquisition of a Benchtop Analytical Scanning Electron Microscope 

Principal Investigator: Deborah Berhanu

Co-Principal Investigator: Karen Peasron

Award Number: 1919563

This Major Research Instrumentation [MRI] fund ($186,635.00), awarded to the Fashion Institute of Technology [FIT], supported the purchase of a Phenom tabletop analytical Scanning Electron Microscope [SEM], its installation and initial 3 year period. The acquisition of the SEM fostered on-campus research and improvements of undergraduate STEAM [Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, Mathematics] education at FIT-SUNY. 

 Specializing in art and design, FIT is reaching across disciplines to better prepare students, integrating the instrument in existing courses and developing new curricula. Exploiting technological advancements and global environmental challenges, the creative industries are now demanding that their professionals possess scientific literacy and interdisciplinary STEAM aptitude necessary to understand the properties of both new and existing materials. The SEM is now integrated into existing courses at FIT including Chemistry for For the Material World, Textile Forensics and Designing with Emerging Materials (as well as others).  Students learn how microscopy imaging works, learn to compare optical and electron microscopy images, fiber characteristics at different magnification, as shown below with cotton (x510 and x1850) and wool (x2300), along with flame and chemical tests to identify fibers. 

The SEM was used in a pioneering course (CUE.NEXT, NSF award CNS-1944777) to run a joint institution course (Arts and Computing in NYC) between FIT and Barnard college, where students were exposed to various technologies and taught the underlying computer science principles. 

Many additional projects that FIT students undertake utilized the SEM as a portion of their  hands-on curricula, and further inter-departmental collaborations are fostered through these projects. 

FIT faculty utilized the SEM to facilitate and expand their research; understanding materials from the past, investigating recycling processes, investigating new materials to enhance sustainability and eliminate plastics, and exploring the future of fashion and art. The SEM has greatly enhanced research capabilities at FIT, especially allowing faculty and students to characterize materials on-site. In an interdisciplinary NSF funded project (#1948422), Stony Brook University and FIT faculty are mentoring students to investigate green chemical routes for the recycling of muslin. The recycled cotton is now being characterized, and FIT undergraduate researchers are being trained to use several instruments, including the SEM. FIT has a strong track record of materials-science innovation through interdisciplinary research. The SEM has allowed us to anchor these projects, and further expand our interdisciplinary collaborations.

Modified by: Deborah Berhanu
